text:
90% of animal feed for ruminants is non edible for humans. We don‚Äôt eat corn stocks. What do you think happens to the almond hulls from your almond milk? They upcycle otherwise wasted food stuffs. 

Methane produced from cattle comes from the plants they eat, which got it from the CO2 they took in from the atmosphere. It‚Äôs cyclical. This isn‚Äôt adding new GHG emissions to the planet. It‚Äôs petroleum fertilizers for crops that do. And more than 50% of fertilizer comes from livestock. Reducing this would mean increasing CO2 emissions due to increasing fossil fuel usage. 

2/3 of agricultural land in the world is non arable, meaning it can‚Äôt grow human foods. Eliminating meat production won‚Äôt mean freeing up land to use. It will mean having less land to use.

You‚Äôre right though, we do have to eat, and choosing what we eat is key. More importantly, choosing how much we don‚Äôt eat. 40% of food in the US is thrown out. Of which, more than 80% is not meat or dairy. In fact, it is said that if food wastage was its own country, it would be the third biggest polluter in the world. 

Meat isn‚Äôt the problem. Reducing meat won‚Äôt save the planet. It will only result in less efficient agricultural practices that actually make things worse. Wasting less food, and using less plastic packaging will do far more.

text:
You‚Äôre not getting it because what these people are saying about cow burps and farts makes no sense.

The life processes of the Earth‚Äôs living beings (animals) is part of the carbon cycle. They ingest carbon (plants), exhale carbon gas (CO2, CH4), and plants uptake that carbon gas, incorporate the carbon into their structure, and that structure is again ingested by the animal. It works that way for humans, cows, dogs, cats, fish, etc., etc.

Cattle do take more resources to raise, and that is reflected in the price of beef vs. pork and poultry. That does not make it unsustainable.

text:
What people are getting wrong, is that tackling climate change is about reducing carbon footprint, not eradicating it. Before coal was used as a fuel, humans still emitted carbon dioxide and methane, but in low levels and were part of the carbon cycle. Before, people still ate cows in large quantities and had dairy yet climate change wasn't a thing back then. 
The solution to this problem is to reduce the amount of beef the average person eats rather than removing it all together. Someone switching from a heavy-beef diet to a moderate-beef diet is so much more effective than from going from vegetarian to vegan diet. 
We don't need to get rid of cows, we juts need to reduce the amount of them. We don't need to get rid of diary all together to tackle it, dairy has been part of the human diet fo so long yet climate change is only a thing now.

text:
How many of you are familiar with these concepts?
Marginal Land vs. Arable Land
Many people ask why not use the land to grow food for humans?" Because you can't. 
-Around 30% of land on the earth is agricultural land (useable for the purpose of making food, the rest is junk).
-Take 66% of that 30% of land. That is "marginal land." 
- Marginal land is not suitable for growing crops due to soil quality or not enough water etc. So what can you do with it? 
-You can have cows graze on the cellulose on this land (again, this land is not suitable for growing edible crops), and turn that cellulose into protein and various nutrients humans need.

Ruminant Upcycling
-33% of that agricultural land mentioned above can be used for crops. (Nice.) This is called "arable land." 
-Though, for every 100lbs of human food produced from crops on this land, roughly 37 lbs of inedible plant byproduct is produced. 
-Cows can eat this inedible plant matter and turn it into protein. 
-Worthless cellulose + Cow = Human Food

Biogenic Carbon Cycle in a nutshell:
-Methane has stronger warming potential than CO2 so cow burp is bad, right? Well...
-Plants capture carbon from the atmosphere via photosynthesis
-Cows eat the plant, take the carbon.
-Cows burp out the carbon in the form of methane (remember methane is CH4 - Carbon, 4 Hydrogens)
-12 yeas later, Methane is broken down back into carbon dioxide via hydroxyl oxidation.
*These carbon molecules are the same molecules that were in the plant the Cow ate. It's a natural cycle. 
(By the way, the carbon dioxide added to the environment by burning fossil fuels (not part of any life cycle) stays in the atmosphere for 200 „Äú 1000 years)

text:
The planet can‚Äôt support meat-eaters

A milions years ago people were vegan before they start to hunt and eat meat.
Not everyone can change their diets, thats the problem. Many people arent willing too because they dont care or they have health problems. Instead of cutting out meat entirely we should try to eat less.Some days we can eat meat and some days we can eat vegetables. 

Giving up meat altogether is not the answer.But we do need to ensure that all livestock are grown healthily with planty of range room and not given hormones or antibiotics.

It pains me to see that the beautiful Amazon forest is being cut down for agricultural purpose and snatching away the homes of thousands of indigenous plants,insects,animals and birds. If humanity actually cared about this we could change the future of generations to come. 

Our consumption habits emit billions of tons of greenhouses gases into atmosphere.

The biggest waster of water is the meat diet. Every 1/4 pound hamburger takes 660 gallon of water to produce. Going to a vegan diet is the biggest way each person can cut there water usage. Going vegan also the best way to mitigate climate change. Animal food production is the biggest contributor of green houses gases at 51 percent. Accounts for 90 percent of deforestation, and biggest cause of ocean dead zones. Every pound of meat produced also uses on average one gallon of petroleum to ship, refrigate, and process. Go vegan for the future of humanity, and improve your own health while doing it.

text:
Vox is the rash thinkers.
90% of animal feed for ruminants is non edible for humans. We don‚Äôt eat corn stocks. What do you think happens to the almond hulls from your almond milk? They upcycle otherwise wasted food stuffs. 

Methane produced from cattle comes from the plants they eat, which got it from the CO2 they took in from the atmosphere. It‚Äôs cyclical. This isn‚Äôt adding new GHG emissions to the planet. It‚Äôs petroleum fertilizers for crops that do. And more than 50% of fertilizer comes from livestock. Reducing this would mean increasing CO2 emissions due to increasing fossil fuel usage. 

2/3 of agricultural land in the world is non arable, meaning it can‚Äôt grow human foods. Eliminating meat production won‚Äôt mean freeing up land to use. It will mean having less land to use.

They‚Äôre right though, we do have to eat, and choosing what we eat is key. More importantly, choosing how much we don‚Äôt eat. 40% of food in the US is thrown out. Of which, more than 80% is not meat or dairy. In fact, it is said that if food wastage was its own country, it would be the third biggest polluter in the world. 

Meat isn‚Äôt the problem. Reducing meat won‚Äôt save the planet. It will only result in less efficient agricultural practices that actually make things worse. Wasting less food, and using less plastic packaging will do far more.

text:
Vox is lying to you. 

1. Cattle production is carbon neutral. They do not emit any more carbon dioxide or methane than they take in through grass and other fodder. 

2. Cattle are not as polluting as fossil fuels. Fossil fuels are dug up from the ground and then burned and go into the atmosphere. It is entirely NEW green house gasses that were previous sequestered deep underground. Cattle does not produce NEW gasses. It converts organic material into meat and waste. Nothing is new. That waste and gasses are taken up by plants and bacteria. That makes it a carbon neutral system.

3. Cattle emissions are ground level emissions. They are quickly taken up by plants and bacteria. How else could they grow except by taking up ground level CO2 and other emissions? 

4. Much cattle production in the US doesn't require the clearing of forests. They graze in open areas that already exist. Even if areas are cleared this is no different than for any field crop. Perhaps some fruit and nut crops result in some carbon sequestration but that is nothing compared to the forests that existed there before. 

There are many reasons to not eat meat. Not the least of which is that it is often cruel and wasteful. However, this video falls under the "False Consciousness" rule. They are trying to convince you that it's really cattle that is causing climate change and not the fossil fuel industry. 

Make no mistake. The primary threat to our environment comes from fossil fuels and not cows. 

We could increase cattle production 10 times what it is now on existing grazing and there would be no increase in atmospheric CO2 or methane so long cows would be consuming grass and other fodder as they always have. 

Finally, much cattle production happens in areas where agriculture is not suitable. The notion that cattle is displacing other types of farms in these areas is untrue. Much of the Southwest is given to cattle because they can graze but have little impact on the other animals in the region. This is absolutely opposite of field crops which require the bulldozing of fields and the slaughter of every animal and plant in that area to make room for one single field crop (like corn, or soybeans). Then that field is cleansed every year with a new slaughter to make room for the next crop and this includes the use of pesticides and herbicides (which aren't used in cattle industry). In this sense, cattle production is much less cruel than soybean or wheat production. Not only do the cattle coexist with many other animals but also when you eat a hamburger you've only killed one animal. Eat a soyburger and you've killed hundreds.
author: The.National.Blade

text:
We have to take other factors such as climate, soil and the economy of a country into account as well. Not all soils contain the right nutrients to plant enough crops needed. Moreover, meat is the cheapest protein source you can get, we can see the countries mentioned in the video are not First World countries, so not everyone is privileged enough to buy supplements and crop seeds to change their diet. So unless the people advocating for a diet change decided to sponsor them the resources and technology needed, all of these are just empty talk. 

That's why I find it less convincing when First World countries,  especially those who had already cut down their own forests, producing even more pollution and had already gained the maximum amount of money that they can from the earth's natural resources are trying to educate other people on how to care for the environment.

text: it is not as simple as having people just not eating beef. the consumption of beef is deeply ingrained in many cultures, and without it, many hundreds of millions if not billions of people would lose part of their culture. And according to the UN declaration of human rights "Everyone has the right freely to participate in the cultural life of the community", which includes eating your own food. This is what a lot of people miss out when talking about reduction in agricultural emissions. The best way to reduce emissions is to always go to the source, not the consumer. We need to find better ways to farm cattle and not just halt it entirely.

text: Actually, there is a misunderstanding about contribution of beef in green house emissions specific to Indian context. The statement "beef industry causes global warming" is only true in West, where there is seperate industrial livestock farming for meat. Those breed are fast-growing high weight-gaining category specially grown for meat. They are not much useful for dairy industry, which has other type of breeds. In India, there is no industrial livestock farming for beef. Almost all methane emissions in India is from cattle grown for milk. Our dairy farmers and farms give them for slaughter only once they run dry (no more able to produce milk) which forms major part of beef supply in India. For small farmers, this is the money they use to buy next cow. In fact, beef consumption in India helps reduce methane emission, because they remove such cattle from population, which otherwise will continue to emit it. Point is, dairy farms are major culprits. If anybody genuinely cares about this issue, the best way is reverse "White revolution" and promote reduction milk consumption.

text:
¬†@leave me¬† dairy is the most efficient protein source available. There is few who actually understand the reality of the application of the data in agriculture, and Vox isn‚Äôt one that does. 

90% of animal feed for ruminants is non edible for humans. We don‚Äôt eat corn stocks. What do you think happens to the almond hulls from your almond milk? They upcycle otherwise wasted food stuffs. 

Methane produced from cattle comes from the plants they eat, which got it from the CO2 they took in from the atmosphere. It‚Äôs cyclical. This isn‚Äôt adding new GHG emissions to the planet. It‚Äôs petroleum fertilizers for crops that do. And more than 50% of fertilizer comes from livestock. Reducing this would mean increasing CO2 emissions due to increasing fossil fuel usage. 

2/3 of agricultural land in the world is non arable, meaning it can‚Äôt grow human foods. Eliminating meat production won‚Äôt mean freeing up land to use. It will mean having less land to use.

They‚Äôre right though, we do have to eat, and choosing what we eat is key. More importantly, choosing how much we don‚Äôt eat. 40% of food in the US is thrown out. Of which, more than 80% is not meat or dairy. In fact, it is said that if food wastage was its own country, it would be the third biggest polluter in the world. 

Meat isn‚Äôt the problem. Reducing meat won‚Äôt save the planet. It will only result in less efficient agricultural practices that actually make things worse. Wasting less food, and using less plastic packaging will do far more. And one way to waste less food would be to use food waste as animal feed.
author: Wes Jones

author: Frog Frenzy 5

text: Frog Frenzy 5 It‚Äôs the grass that puts carbon into the soil. When cattle graze it, it takes a bit of the carbon stored in the leaves, but also makes the plant work to rebuild that eaten bit and if managed properly, will also then build its root system putting carbon underground. Putting a bit of stress on the grass plant like grazing it actually makes it grow more both above and below ground.

text: It really depends on where and how grazing animals would be good for the environment. If land must be cleared, aka forests (looking at Brazil here), its a net negative. However if it is to put back nutrients into depleted soil then its great. However most ranching is done for profit and not to restock soil due to "inefficient" land usage (far more land needs to be used if cattle are to graze rather then feed on fodder and grain). As a whole if land in areas where soils are depleted or is subject to desertification then it would help the environment locally. This is due to the land being already depleted you still need to provide feed otherwise the grazing animals will starve. There was a good TED talk about this a number of years ago if you want to search for it.

One of the biggest helps was finding out how varied and helpful vegan channels on youtube were in giving me meat alternatives or vegetable recipes that weren't at all like the vegetables I grew up with. Just know that there's so many people out there who will be patient and support you through any kind of large dietary change. Never pressure yourself, and just go at your own pace. text: ‚Äã¬†@Dan Pech¬† So if everyone stopped eating beef tomorrow, what do we do with all the cows? Do we release them back into the wild and let them breed freely?
author: Policy Police

text: ¬†@Policy Police¬† Why is the scenario always some catastrophic one of 100% of the world's population going vegan overnight? When has any change in history been like this? I don't think even the most optimistic person actually thinks that everyone will abstain from eating beef overnight. A more likely scenario is a gradual reduction in beef consumption, followed by gradual reduction in the amount of animals being raised by producers. I'm sure this would lead to a gradual change in agricultural business models and cattle would be slowly phased out in favor of other, more sustainable uses of land and resources.
author: Dan Pech

text:
Oh believe me, the airline industry is most definitely looking forward to not burning fuel. Fuel is heavy to carry and also by far airlines' #1 cost.

The problem is that current solar and battery technology does not allow enough power to propel an airplane while making it light enough to fly. As soon as that technology is available, you will see a huge transition into green airplanes.

Meanwhile, cars, trucks, trains, cruise ships, container ships, all have the technology to change into greener engines, but they don't care.

text:
So the choice is between cheese burgers and planet Earth? I think I can live without the planet Earth.üòÅ

In all seriousness, though, this isn't just a story about the foods themselves, but also about the mismanagement of resources. It wouldn't matter if we cut down on beef because what is getting destroyed to raise and prep those animals for food would instead get destroyed to produce some other economically viable product. The people in charge of destroying the rainforest for beef aren't going to just get better management practices just because the cows are out of the picture. Fixing this requires encouraging or enforcing a change in the priorities of those destroying the rainforest, cow or no cow.

By the way, I did 'like' the video. It is informational and a decent thought piece.

text: Actually, there is a misunderstanding about contribution of beef in green house emissions specific to Indian context. The statement "beef industry causes global warming" is only true in West, where there is seperate industrial livestock farming for meat. Those breed are fast-growing high weight-gaining category specially grown for meat. They are not much useful for dairy industry, which has other type of breeds. In India, there is no industrial livestock farming for beef. Almost all methane emissions in India is from cattle grown for milk. Our dairy farmers and farms give them for slaughter only once they run dry (no more able to produce milk) which forms major part of beef supply in India. For small farmers, this is the money they use to buy next cow. In fact, beef consumption in India helps reduce methane emission, because they remove such cattle from population, which otherwise will continue to emit it. Point is, dairy farms are major culprits. If anybody genuinely cares about this issue, the best way is reverse "White revolution" and promote reduction milk consumption.

text:
Thanks for your informative videos. Doesn't carbon per calorie make more sense for comparing food source carbon emissions? 1kg of tomatoes 180 calories, 1kg of bananas 890 calories, 1kg of chicken 2,390, 1 kg of beef 2,500 calories. Also, what about regenerative agriculture and the need to use animal feces in order to avoid using fertilizers to gain topsoil and sequester more carbon? What about raising animals on grasslands not suitable for agriculture? Also, animals can be fed bacteria to change there microbiome in order to severely reduce their methane production. There is no doubt that the way most animals are raised not is terrible but a regenerative agriculture model is better for the environment than a vegan model due to the increased topsoil, reduced fertilizers and increased carbon sequestering in the soil. If people are informed about better choices they will demand it and suppliers will fulfill this demand.
For water-use, almonds use a lot but they can only grow in a very specific climate. In the US cattle farmers use the same region. If the cattle farmers converted to almond farming then the cattle could be raised in a region with more water and a different climate. As stated almonds and very good for carbon emissions and they can be distributed with minimal waste due to spoiling and have a long shelf life. Most farmers already use drip irrigation. If farmers in the almond regions of the US changed their water use then the almonds would not take the brunt of the water shortage issues in the only regions they can grow. The entire system needs a rethink with a holistic view.

text:
x0RRY Videos like this hurt the beef industry. Livestock raisers already have a hard time making money off of live meat the way it is. Anyway, agriculture is an extremely complex process and I don‚Äôt expect you or this video to completely understand the entire thing. The video mostly talked about farming beef in the rainforests without mentioning livestock raising in the United States or other parts of the world where we have hilly prairies with rock patches and varying climates that cannot be used to grow crops with current agricultural technology. They actually believe that we could convert all areas used for cattle into rice fields and such when this simply isn‚Äôt the case. In fact, cultivating native grasses to make way for other crops negatively impacts the environment. There are certain methods of raising beef that take carbon out of the air but I won‚Äôt go into detail. As you know, cattle produce manure. This is a far better alternative for fertilizer than the synthetic chemicals used otherwise. Vox is made up of city people and they don‚Äôt care about agriculture or the folks that bust their backs to feed a growing population of unthankful people. 
If you read all that, thanks.
author: Troy T

text:
¬†@Troy T¬† While you make some good points, the beef industry and livestock raisers should never be a priority for decisions which are nessecary for our planet so survive.

Yes, you can produce beef in a more environmentally friendly way, but at the end of the day, the population grows and grows. As people in 3rd World countries get richer, they also want more meat. And this demand will not be satisfied with cattle from otherwise unusuable hills. The long term goal HAS to be, to drastically reduce our consumption of beef.
author: mib

text: ¬†@Troy T¬† There are methods that take carbon out of the air, but that doesn't make them environmentally friendly. No cattle farming method is carbon neutral or carbon negative. Also, given that this video is less than 5 minutes long, vox couldn't go into every detail, and had to oversimplify a fair amount.

text:
my take on this as an agricultural engineering student is that this is a far too complex topic to just make a 5 min video and by the end just basically say 'don't eat beef'

While the majority of us should have a more balanced diet and consume less meat, 'no beef!' isn't exactly the conclusion you should come to. I don't want to type out an essay but the fact that animal agriculture has a bad reputation is only partly based on facts. I am really curious about which sources were used here for example bc in our university most of the stats tell a different story, that beef is contributing to it, but not the biggest cause for climate change.

Most of us folks who are active in the agricultural field are trying our best to improve farming practices etc. but most people I've met (profs, farmers, vets) aren't against beef production/animal agriculture. And I'll take their word over that of youtube channels/news outlets any day.

I am honestly a bit surprised about this video bc I genuinely enjoy most of vox's content. But this is just oversimplyfing a giant system of problems and that isn't doing anybody any good. So yeah, disappointed to say the least.

text: The topic of beef production is way more complicated then how Vox is portraying it. The world agriculture society has found that we have around 60 years worth of harvest left due to the way we have degraded our soil due to poor farming practices such as monocultures where a single kind of crop is grown over and over again with the use of synthetic fertilises and sprays. I seriously encourage people to look up ‚Äúwhite oak pastures‚Äù they are producing beef and other animal products with a carbon negative out put (which means they are taking more carbon out of the atmosphere then what they‚Äôre producing). sustainable agriculture is no longer good enough we need to move to a regenerative agriculture system which needs grazing animals.

text: The problem is the fact that our medieval forbearers; Serfs, Peasants, the Bourgeoisie did not consume Beef on a monthly or even daily basis. They depended on local ingredients; Fish (Salmon, Cod, Carp, Trout, Eels), Vegetables, Fruits, Nuts, Healthy Fats. They only probably ate things like Beef or Pork as a luxury, like Sausages and Pot Pies. They made Soups and Stews of Hearty Vegetables. In our modern world we consume processed goods and mass produced Fatty meat like (Beef, Pork, Chicken) on a regular basis, which is terrible for us and the environment. Veganism isn‚Äôt the answer, we just need to adopt the diet habits of our ancestors before us.

text:
I totally get the point of the video and would say eating less or no beef is clearly a good way to reduce emissions. But I think it might give a more honest picture of how polluting a type of food is if you factor in the amount of calories per kg. For instance producing 1 kg of wheat results in more emissions than producing 1 kg of tomatoes. But when looking at how much you would need to eat a day to sustain your needs you need a lot more kg of tomatoes then kg of wheat.

A quick Google results in whole grain wheat having 3400 calories per kg and tomatoes having only 177 calories per kg. A more then 19 times difference. This to me at least makes eating wheat a better option then eating tomatoes. When only looking at the environmental impact and not at the amount of micronutrients or fiber.

Would love to hear what you think!

text: Where was the comparison of nutritional value of the foods? Where was the acknowledgement of mono-cropping produce killing the soil and leading to 50 harvests remaining situation? Where was the graphs showing the massive disparities in food waste, it's even more significant contribution to GHG, and how meat is the least wasted food? Where was the explanation that methane is a small fraction of total GHG and that it lives in a cycle and effectively dies after 10 years whereas CO2 lives for hundreds? Where was the explanation of how grass fed free range ruminants are GHG sinks and revitalize once dead crop land? Where was the statistic showing that 2/3rd of the earth is unsuitable for crop production but is suitable for livestock? Where was the statistic that the entire US going vegan would have a 3% reduction in GHG produced while fossil fuels create 75% of emissions. Why was the focus on clearing forests for ruminants use not focusing on the governments of those countries allowing it? Where was the explanation that cow fertilizer is a naturally perfect product for growth of natural grassland? This video is intentionally deceptive and damning of one of the single most healthy human food sources there is, and one of the only types of animals that can reduce global warming by simply being alive and doing their thing. Anyone genuinely curious should follow Frank Mitloehner (@GHGGuru) on Twitter to begin learning about the real consequences and contributions of ruminants on our planet and species.

text:
Honestly I don't think this is presented fair and should be presented as possible higher emission because of meat. 

The reason: there is still today many doubts about if all and correct data is evaluated into this. The number of parameters that impact the result is complex and can not be this simplified. For example, what level is this measured at (a canned tomatoes has a much higher impact than meat), how is halftime of methane compared to CO2, how is the environment impact from meat compared to other type of production because the benefit of other environmental factor can in turn improve carbon upptake at other places in the natural cycle.

With this I don't mean that beef has a much better carbon emissions compared to the other food stuff, but we really don't know if it is really this high as presented at many places.

There are many many other thing that can be done that we know will benefit the environment today, just what and how we use everyday products, 

and maybe making charts in the computer than using paper ;)

author: sd va

text:
It's the worst food for climate, yes. Indeed cattle production does emit a whole lot of methane, but it only looks as bad if you aren't including the other greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide. 

When you include them all as a whole, agriculture only produce around 8-9% greenhouse gases, which is still considered low if you compare it to transportation (27%) and electricity (35%). 

I do agree we need to control our consumption of beef. But this video is the typical kind that tries to look down on agriculture, especially on beef cattles.

text:
You need to adjust the chart based upon viable protein content and include water consumption.  A gallon of water for a single almond.  5 gallons for a walnut.  Large mono-cultures eventually ruin the soil.  You really can't have plants without animals/insects.
Although I agree that the methane cows burp is significant, this is being worked on and cows produce a lot more beneficial products than just beef and methane.  A sustainable cow farm (technically a grass farm), produces milk, butter, cheeze, beef (and probably chickens and eggs as part of the process),  potentially captures some of the methane for fuel, and has a digester that produces more fuel and significant amounts of fertilizer.
The answer isn't eliminating cows or cow farms, it's eliminating farms that aren't sustainable, regardless of product.

text: Actually, there is a misunderstanding about contribution of beef in green house emissions specific to Indian context. The statement "beef industry causes global warming" is only true in West, where there is seperate industrial livestock farming for meat. Those breed are fast-growing high weight-gaining category specially grown for meat. They are not much useful for dairy industry, which has other type of breeds. In India, there is no industrial livestock farming for beef. Almost all methane emissions in India is from cattle grown for milk. Our dairy farmers and farms give them for slaughter only once they run dry (no more able to produce milk) which forms major part of beef supply in India. For small farmers, this is the money they use to buy next cow. In fact, beef consumption in India helps reduce methane emission, because they remove such cattle from population, which otherwise will continue to emit it. Point is, dairy farms are major culprits. If anybody genuinely cares about this issue, the best way is reverse "White revolution" and promote reduction milk consumption.

text: This video would be great if it weren't for one fatal flaw. Methane production from cows DOES NOT CONTRIBUTE TO GLOBAL WARMING. Cows are part of a natural carbon cycle. They eat grass/grain, made of carbon which was fixed from CO2 in the atmosphere. They eat the grass and digest it. They then emit CO2 and methane, carbon which was already located in the grass and is now in the air again to be fixed by plants. It is completely separate from fossil fuel carbon, which is introduction CO2 into the air which had been trapped in rocks for millions of years. The number of cows in the United States has not been increasing, in fact it has been decreasing in the past two decades due to genetics and better management practice. This means that beef/dairy production has actually contributed to global cooling! Also, looking at these systems from a global standpoint doesn't make sense. Beef you and I eat comes from America, where we literally have millions of acres of ground in the western part of the United States which is too poor to grow crops on but is only adequate for ruminant use (animals which turn stuff we cannot eat, such as grass, into extremely nutritious foods). This one misconception about GHG emissions alone (due to kg CO2 equivalents which are not a good way to compare livestock to other industries) is creating extremely dangerous misconceptions against farmers/ranchers and their products.

text:
According to Beef Market Central, the US consumes about 21% of the world's beef. China is next at 14% (but with ~5x the population), followed closely by Brazil and the EU, both at around 13% (Brazil is ~50% of EU population).


Per capita, the ratings change a bit between sources, because different organizations use different standards to measure consumption, but the generally agreed trend is that the highest per capita consumers are North and South Americans (notably US, Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina, Chile, and Canada) along with Australia, Kazakhstan, Hong Kong, and Israel.

text:
¬†@Sie, Evan Setiawan¬† The calculations still treat the impact of methane as if it stays in the atmosphere indefinitely like CO2, whereas it actually has about a 10 year lifecycle, returning back to the soil. 

It also assumes that cattle is fed anything other than grass, which certainly is problematic and we shouldn't do. It would be more effective for the environment to advocate against factory farming practices as opposed to advocating against beef altogether since the restoration and maintenance of natural grasslands with the help of rumenants contributes to carbon dioxide sequestration and replenishment of valuable top soil.
author: enerjustics

text:
Does that mean methane absorption rate 10 years later is same as methane release rate now?
Or the absorption rate is constant and we have to keep release rate below absorption rate?
author: Sie, Evan Setiawan

text: Sie, Evan Setiawan As long as the number of rumenants stays on the current level, their contribution is overall positive since it leads to CO2 sequestration (which interestingly enough can't be achieved with planting trees for example). We do however want to avoid global warming from further CO2 emission since that eventually will lead to frozen methane being released from the ground, accelerating the CO2 damage. So overall, methane release and resorption works in a cycle, CO2 release however is problematic since it just adds up and stays in the atmosphere

author: Mariuta Nicolae

text:
Beef is both unhealthy and bad for the environment. But many of course will put their enjoyment of eating beef before their own health so it¬¥s not surprising that pollution is even less of a motivation to cut consumption. The state is reluctant to take any measures that reduce domestic cattle industries, but they could put a high toll on imported beef products to discourage its consumption, that would at least reduce pollution from transportation and reduction of some cattle production around the world. 
If we all just cut our consumption of meat and in particular beef just a few kg each year it could have a huge impact. That would be something like eating ONE meal a week without meat. Or put it another way, ONE meal a week where you feed your body lots of vegetables, pulses, legumes etc.
I love beef but we really shouldn¬¥t be eating it as a regular source of protein.

text:
You could do sequel to episode about crops that require the most water. We have many places in the world that have had or are facing zero days. In Australia, we have a '"water buyback" scheme for the Murray-Darling Basin (Australia's food bowl. Which stretches from Queensland through NSW all the way to Victoria). It was meant to be a way of balancing the use of water by limiting the volume of water that farmers could extract from the river. The government 'buys back' water entitlements from growers, thereby reducing the amount of water taken from the river. 

Now you don't need to be a farmer to own water entitlements, in fact the Chinese and the US are the biggest investors in our water entitlements. The government was caught paying $80 million of tax payers money to company that is registered to the Cayman Islands.

Last year during our summer (which is very dry) water stopped flowing in the rivers causing large blue-green algae blooms which starved oxygen to all the fish. Millions of fish were killed and seen floating in the river. While there was a drought and lot of finger pointing on to blame, what we need to remember is that the basin can only support so much. Why are we growing things like cotton, chestnuts and rice? Things that require so much water. We should be growing things that suit our climate. This is why a follow up video to this one but about water usage I think is important for people to know.

text:
We might care about climate change, but we might have an eating disorder. 
I suffered from anorexia for 17 years. I was an ethical vegan for 10 years. Vegetarian for 14. 
I'm not alone. Restricting food groups is one main of the characteristics of eating disorders. 
A lot of people suffer from eating disorders. And being vegan is a good way to disguise it. I was proud to do what was good for the planet. I was dying. (A few vegan would say that is a good thing, that people are just a nuisance to life).
I think that reducing rather then eliminating is the answer. Eating better quality meat, less often.

text: Not consuming animal products is definitely something that we should all take up, however minimally... but I think that there's a myth to the "our" and "we" when we talk about destroying the planet. As much as we have the agency to change our diets, the truth is that the corporations in charge of these industries are the ones responsible for producing carbon emissions exponentially over the past few decades. We cannot keep convincing ourselves that being conscious of what we eat is enough, but rather being conscious of the systemic exploitation of the land/people that really explain why we're in the state we're in. The truth is, not everyone will go vegan, but everyone can consume foods that are grown and produced locally and sustainably. I care about climate change, but the people with the real power to change things simply do not‚Äìthat is the problem.

Funny they never talk about it though... It goes against the push to make everyone vegan even though it's better for the environment and your health.
author: Blair Maffin

text: ¬†@coopaloopvt¬† Yeah, but 1 kilo of meat feeds you for a day or two. You can compare that to how long 1 kg of rice will feed you, or 1 kg of potatoes. 1 kg of coffee, doesn't feed you at all (I mean, you can try, it is edible, but it isn't good for you). Coffee is more of a lifestyle choice than a food source, it just so happens that you make coffee by farming, rather than mining or something.
author: Boosterh

text:
¬†@Richard¬† Hello an enviormental activist here. We are trying to get people to drive less and opt for public transport but no matter what we say or do it will always come down to the people themselves and big corporations. We cannot change the law by ourselves with the snap of a finger, we need politicians and more people to support the idea of a livable planet.

In theory it could be possible to move cattle from South America to Alberta. But that is only in theory. In reality lands like Alberta couldn't handle the amount of cattle we are currently raising. It would also limit biodiversity if we were to only raise cattle in a sertain enviorment. There would also be logistical problems like where would all the food for cattle be produces and how much emissions would it produce with transportation included. There would also be the problem of antibiotic resistanse wich is growing at an alarming rate the more we consume animal products. Those animals are pumped full of meds to keep them from getting disease. Around 85-90% of the worlds antibiotics are used within animal agriculture.

 Those same animals are still creating greenhouse gasses like CO2 and methane when they are alive. At this rate we are raising and killing millions of animals per day just to keep up with the demand for meat etc. It doesn't  matter where they are raised they still weaken biodiversity everywhere wich also contributes to climate change.

 We know that raising cattle and dairy cows is someones livelihood but should it be? Animal agriculture is the least sustainable diet to keep up no matter how you try to twist it.
author: Siiri V

text: There are other comparisons online for per calories and it just looks equally bad
author: Rishabh Goyal

text:
¬†@Siiri V¬† please go research regenerative agriculture and come back.

Ranchers are currently able to have a heard 3x the size vs the "normal" method on the same patch of land. They are improving soil quality. They are pulling carbon out of the atmosphere and not contributing. All the cows eat is grass. No need to ship in any other food or water.

It is the way ranching should be done.
author: Blair Maffin

text: ¬†@Blair Maffin¬† How can they pull carbon out when they are living animals burning food?
author: Aj

text:
¬†@Blair Maffin¬† So the idea is that their manure accumulates more rapidly? so the grass (or whatever) grows very quickly plus it can sustain thrice the amount of cattle that usually eats mostly concentrate? Sounds hard to believe, where is all that extra energy coming from?
It likely doesn't use synthetic fertilizers to grow meadows (so less grass), but you can keep thrice the number of cattle on it?
I love the concept, but I don't see how this works unless you dump an equal portion of human waste on those meadows. And even then I doubt natural composting is fast enough.

Ofcourse it cuts down the emissions in for example their food intake since they are eating mostly stuff from the ground beneath them. text:
You might not finish a kilo of chocolate for a couple weeks, eating it as snacks/dessert, but if you tried to live off of, say chocolate covered coffee beans, you'd probably polish off a 1 kilo bag in a day or two (I've seen people try). The only reason you eat them more slowly is because you are bulking out your diet with rice/wheat/chicken etc.


Now, for a truly fair comparison you'd have to assign each food a kind of overall nutritional score to get a comparison of food value vs environmental damage, but that would be a mathematical nightmare, comparing protein vs carbs vs vitamins and trying to come up with a single number.

text: ¬†@Upen Shenoy¬† You realize that a cow needs to be pregnant to start producing milk? It is impossible to have milk without also farming cows. If you want to have them ‚Äúproduce milk throughout her lifetime‚Äù, you have to impregnate the cow regularly. Being pregnant all the time is not sustainable for the cow, hence they usually get slaughtered a couple of years into their lives, when they don‚Äôt produce enough milk anymore (because their bodies just cannot do it anymore). It might be better, but a nutmilk or an oat milk is much, much more sustainable, and that all without the associated animal cruelty, like forced impregnation.

text: Industrial agriculture and livestock practices are terrible across the board, and people living the standard American diet consume far too much meat. However, please look into intensive silvopasture (agroforestry practice) combined with diversified perennial prairie grasses. Project Drawdown identifies this practice as one of the best ways we can mitigate climate change from CO2 and GHG emissions. We eat too much meat but tilling the ground every year for grains and vegetables is also unlikely to resolve our issues. A diverse application of regenerative farming and agroforestry practices (including livestock management and consumption) is more likely to benefit the Earth and feed more people.

text:
I think this video is over simplifying this. The problem is not eating beef. Like one of the comments says, cows have been around for a long time and humans have been eating them for a really long time too. The problem is how animal farming is done. 

I think first we should reevaluate how we farm these animals and how the carbon footprint for these processes can be reduced. A lot of people rely on meats, especially beef for nutritional purposes as well as just eating it for its taste. 

The majority of this video is criticising the farming processes so why would you conclude that we should just stop eating beef altogether! At least make a comment on finding better ways to farm or carbon recapture. There's loads of other things to say/conclude from this video than the one size fits all that you've done.

text:
The land use change in chocolate are higher than palm oil. It doesn't make sense! 
I live in Indonesia where 14,3 million Hectares are use for palm oil plantation and most of it are peatlands. 3:38 it's a peatland in Indonesia. They're draining the area for palm oil plantation not for chocolate. Peatland are wetlands whose soils consist almost entirely of organic matter that are not fully dacayed because it's too wet to decomposet. The wetlands store vast amount of carbon, twice as much carbon as all the world's forests. Clearing and draining the peatlands causes the opposite effect. Causing huge greenhouse gas emissions and also making wetlands vulnerable to fires. It happened last year. Most of the time they just burnt the lands causing more emissions. So the land use change in Palm oil it's supposed to be much much higher.

text: This is talking about factory farming not well raised cows! A very important distinction. When cows have a diet of pasture grasses instead of corn and grain, they produce far less methane. They also have the opportunity to support grass root growth through grazing which sequesters carbon. I agree that humans should eat less beef, but I also think they should eat better beef. Please consider supporting local organic cattle farmers. There are people out there doing it right, and eating beef can be a positive thing to support them and the environment. Another thing to think about is the fertilizer cows can provide in a positive farm system. If we hope to move away from chemical fertilizers which contaminate land, water, and wildlife we need to pursue sustainable fertilizers. Cattle can contribute to this system with their manure. Overall this issue is incredibly complicated but the most important thing to realize is not all cattle are raised equally (both environmentally and ethically) and it‚Äôs possible to be an active consumer and choose good beef!

text: I wouldn't sweat it too much - remember that Vox's graph isn't accounting for the fact that typical serving sizes for these foods generally vary a lot in weight. A kilogram of beef for example only comprises about 4 individual steaks, whereas a kilo of coffee beans can stretch to make around 100 cups of coffee. Even though coffee or cocoa might contribute about a quarter of the greenhouse emissions as beef per unit mass, we typically consume (and thus produce) these foods in quantities much lower than products like meat or fruit or grains, and so their relative impact is actually less than this in practice. The same can be said of foods like olive oil or nuts, which are calorie-dense. So enjoy your morning brew!

text:
¬†@TheFeldhamster¬† No, thank God. I live in the UK so we had a major foot and mouth outbreak so my family stopped consuming beef. So I now no longer have the enzymes or gut bacteria to digest it.
It was um... fun finding that out.
author: Kay'la Sen

text:
¬†@Kay'la Sen¬† TLDR: People add meat back into their diets too quickly, and it makes them sick because they have to build the correct enzymes back up.


While I cannot know for certain, I do not think you are actually allergic to beef. I'm a vegetarian, I have been since I was three years old, so I haven't eaten any meat or fish for a solid amount of time. And of course, because of this, my body doesn't produce enough enzymes and stuff to actually process and digest meat. Thus if I tried eating a hamburger right now, I'd end up extremely sick. However, there have been a number of vegetarians and vegans who at one point stop being vegetarian/vegan. They also end up being sick if they don't GRADUALLY add meat back into their diet. Your body, unless you are truly allergic, still has those enzymes to digest meat, just not enough of them by a long shot, and thus you'll end up making yourself sick. So people trying to get back into eating meat, have to do it very gradually, its a process because you are basically teaching your body how to digest meat again. Of course, I can't know if you are truly allergic or not, nor are you required to actually go and eat meat again, but I've seen enough people think they are allergic to meat when they really are just adding it into their diet too quickly.
author: BleepBlopBloop

text: ¬†@BleepBlopBloop¬† I would agree with you. An "allergy" is an immune response.

text: Sounds like you have beef intolerance, rather than a true allergy to beef.

text: ¬†@BleepBlopBloop¬† I know an older woman, a young grandmother basically, who loves red meat and ate lots of it during her life. Roughly 2 or 3 years ago, she developed a red meat allergy. Like, even a bite will have her very sick. I'm guessing there's a certain point where the enzymes won't, or can't come back. Obviously, age probably plays into it, but I wouldn't be surprised if people couldn't even handle small amounts to take it in slowly.

text: Changing your diet will not stop global warming. As farming is a natural cycle. It has existed way longer then the using of fossil fuels, so if farming was having a big affect on the planet, global warming would have started to increase parallel with  farming but it did not. A better alternate is to think about the affects outside of the cycle, and try to source local goods instead of shipping goods from around the world. The more local the product the better it is, as it is the products that have to be shipped (cocoa products, cheep meats and unnative crops) that have the damaging affect on our planet. But is local farms are not supported then it will be the larger, more intensive and inhumane farms that survive and replace the smaller farms that are not aible to compete.

text: I think that is the only mis-step in an otherwise great video. It seems to me that the 28% is the average % of a person's emissions that are due to food production. If that's the case, then the only way to achieve 28% reduction is to not eat anything! Obviously this is impossible. From memory, I think that a vegan diet only emits about 30-35% of a beef-heavy diet (don't quote me), if that helps? So if I'm right you could probably knock 10-20% off your personal emissions, depending on how much beef you eat and your other personal lifestyle factors.

text: 2:33 oil & gas and coal mining are the only categories that matter in this chart because they are the only ones that release carbon from the lithosphere. Biogenic methane is much less important to climate change since it was initially excracted carbon from the atmosphere on a short timescale and is converted from methane to carbon dioxide by solar radiation. The rate of generation has a marginal effect on the equilibrium concentration (not as relevent as a process that creates accumulation) however changes in land use may have also decreased the natural rate of methane release by the biosphere for example from coversion of wetland to farmland. Wetlands, without the presence of higher than normal concentrations of sulfates, release a large amount of methane.

I'm responding to how the information is presented in this video/description which seems to be heavily suggesting that a small change in diet can be more powerful than any other decision (including transportation), but that math doesn't check out... I checked. It also has many assumptions. Most people drive everyday, very few people eat beef everyday. And what if I eat beef once a week? or more realistically once a month? There are many assumptions in this data. Certainly, less is better but I'm highlighting that large change is more than just minor reductions. It's about making serious lifestyle improvements that shift the conversation drastically - again, a drastic transportation adjustment, like we've recently witnessed, will most certainly be more beneficial than a very minor diet adjustment, and both - great!

text: Yes, so there are two bars for milk instead of one (milk and dairy) which is an odd decision to begin with. And, additionally those two bars are far shorter than the beef bar. So if I read the graph drinking milk has almost no impact whatsoever (going by the milk bar alone) which completely ignores where the milk comes from (that would be the other bar) and on top of that the dairy bar is less than half of the beef bar without any explanation. So please enlighten me
author: Josua Krause

text:
¬†@Josua Krause¬† What's so hard to get? Dairy cows and beef cows are rared differently, so it's only natural they'll have different bars. 

A dairy cow can produce a lot of milk over it's life time, so of course it's emissions per kg of product will be much lower than beef, since you know, a cow can only be slaughtered once? 

It's not hard to figure out, it's even easier to click on the source in the description that explains everything.
author: l0lwutwtf

text: ¬†@l0lwutwtf¬† the majority of the cow emissions come from the methane. Dairy cows don't produce less of that.
author: Josua Krause

text: ¬†@Josua Krause¬† The research paper says otherwise.
author: l0lwutwtf

text: ¬†@l0lwutwtf¬† No it doesn't. Actually, the notes on the original graph (in the link) state exactly that. It just gets distributed across more products. And you can see that cheese is right up there with dairy beef. My initial complaint was about this splitting up since it hides the total impact of dairy products (since the emissions are distributed across those products) which would otherwise come close to non-dairy beef. You cannot look at the low milk footprint without also looking at dairy-beef and cheese since you would not have milk without those cows.
author: Josua Krause

text: ¬†@Josua Krause¬† If you add up all the products, you'll need to divide it by the number of products because the graph is per 1kg of product.
author: l0lwutwtf

text: ¬†@l0lwutwtf¬† you cannot simply add up the bars because of this. They should have included a total dairy bar since 1kg of beef at the end of the life of a cow is not comparable to 1kg of milk throughout the life. And you cannot have the milk without having the cow emissions that play into the dairy beef bar (I guess you could throw away the beef but then it would just be wasted and it wouldn't change any of the emissions leading up to that point). That's why I'm saying you cannot look at the low milk bar while ignoring the dairy beef bar
author: Josua Krause

text:
¬†@Josua Krause¬† What do you think the milk bar represents if you say the cow emissions don't play a role in it? 

A dairy cow can produce more products so naturally, while the emissions from the cows itself may not differ much, the emissions per product per weight is going to be different.

text: It‚Äôs accurate. The green circle should occupy 1/21 times the area of the yellow circle. This means that it‚Äôs diameter should be 1/(21^0.5) times the diameter of the yellow circle, which is roughly 1/4.5 . The diameter of the yellow circle is 4.5 times the diameter of the green circle.
author: Prateek Wadhavkar

text:
Yeah, what I think happened is that they got diameter and radius confused when calculating the area. Measuring the circles in paint and doing some napkin math:
r1=0.33", r2=2.92", so r2/r1=8.85. Applying A=pi*r^2, A2/A1=8.85^2=78.3. 
So what happened? Theory #1: they didn't half 21 when doing the calculation, using diameter instead of radius. 
Check: if r2a=0.5*r2=8.85/2=4.425, then A2/A1=4.425^2=19.6. This is close enough to 21 that given human error in measurements, theory #1 stands as a definite maybe.

text:
The real solution (in my opinion) to the beef problem is not to say ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt eat it‚Äô, because although some of us try to reduce our intake or even eliminate it completely, there are other people that are not willing to do it and they have their right to do it, so the wheel keeps turning in favor of big corporations. So in the end, even though it is a good action, it is not addressing the real problem. What we should do is DEMAND A CHANGE in the way beef is raised and produced, so we address the real problem. 

If you want some information and you care about our soils you can find interesting some of the following topics/examples: regenerative agriculture, the savory institute, Rodale institue or just permaculture. Also great examples are Joel Salatin, Joyce Farms, Charles Massy or Stoney Creek Farm. Maybe you have a farm near where you live and you can take action. Buying beef from this kind of farms is the best way to change practices and habits in this industry. Cows, bison, etc.. can actually be one of the best tools we have (along with biochar) to store carbon in our soils and reverse climate change.

But I‚Äôm not saying let‚Äôs eat a cow a day so we can reduce climate change, I‚Äôm saying reduce your intake and we you actually buy beef try to buy it from regenerative farms (local being the ideal).

Hope this is useful for someone. Have a great day.

text:
Besides cattle, new sources of methane have been adding to the problem. They are due to global warming. One is methane deposits in the seafloor that are being released. Also, as arctic ice melts in Siberia, Canada, and Greenland methane deposits from the permafrost underneath is being released. Finally, in the US, the rise of fracking has resulted in the fracking process leaking lots of methane into the atmosphere. NASA has tracked a huge rise in methane emissions from what's called the Permian Basin, which is the land in the midwest US where fracking is the most prevalent. 
Methane is probably a big contributor to the reason why global warming seems to be happening faster than predicted. If you just use CO2 in the predictions and leave out methane, you will get less warming which takes longer to reach tipping point levels. But add in the methane, which doesn't last as long but makes the temperature rise more quickly, and you have a real problem that is growing faster than expected.

text:
‚Ä¢ Cheese gets a separate bar because on top of milk's emissions, it makes more from processing it into cheese.
‚Ä¢ The milk bar is milk from non-cow sources (which is actually rare outside of North America), so it's low.
‚Ä¢ Cow-milk, which is a mainly western thing, requires cows plus processing, which is why it's so high.
‚Ä¢ Beef also requires cows, but also requires a lot of extra processing which further increases its emissions.
‚Ä¢ One cow can produce milk repeatedly, but it can produce beef only once, hence beef is so much higher than milk.
This makes this video look ironic.

author: Red User

text:
¬†@Red User¬† Even though you are right with taking the companies into responsibility to protect climate and nature I think you are wrong to say that this should be a measure taken before the measures we talked about just now.
Because of climate change being absolutely serious and dangerous and us having literraly no more time to prevnt it we should take every serious action now, not one after another, but all as soon as possible.
Yes, China is one of the biggest problems, but as you yourself said it is not that easy for us to tell them to simply change. So what do you suppose should we do in that regard?
author: Marvin Jung

text:
¬†@Red User¬† For whatever reason I am unable to see your comment. I received a notification that you did indeed wrote one, but now there is none to respond too.
Would you be so kind to once again write what you commented?
author: Marvin Jung

text:
¬†@Marvin Jung¬† No problem, mate. Here it is:


What do you mean by 
I think you are wrong to say that this should be a measure taken before the measures we talked about just now.
I didn't understand that part. I don't support that we should disincentivize eating beef by implementing taxes or supply caps, by the way.
author: Red User

text:
¬†@Red User¬† From what you originally said I though you meant that these measures are not per se worng but should only be implemented AFTER taking big companies and the economy into responsibility. What I now meant was that, because of the climate crisis being one of the most serious problems humankind will ever face, we should implement every serious measure as soon as possible, at best right now.
Why do you not support disincentivizing such behaviour? To direct behaviour by several measure, incentives and disincentive, is a common practice used by governments and one ceartainly needed in this situation. The negative effects included in such measures, especially the social ones mentioned by me before, can be avoided.
author: Marvin Jung

text: ¬†@Marvin Jung¬† I don't believe the government holds any legitimate power to do so, it would simply be meddling in our freedom. Besides, it wouldn't make that much of a change. I also think that it would unrelate the focus from the bigger problem and it would discourage further people from supporting the movement since they would see it as tool for the government to intervene in our personal lives.
author: Red User

text:
¬†@Red User¬† Of course actions by governments most often harm the individuals freedom, and that indeed is an important counter argument but politics, especially in ethical questions like these, allways is the balancing of different aspects and interests, meaning that in this case freedom is rivaling with solidarity and the protection of nature. You can come to the conclusion that the positive in this case does not outweigh the negatives, I would differ, that is something everyone will have to answer for themselves.
But I do think that most people, at least in my home country, actually do support such measures making specific products more expensive, that has been shown by several surveys. It is thus, in my opinion, an acceptbale solution if, and that is important, you make this solution work for the ones not being able to have the choice do buy higher priced goods because of their lack of income and wealth, meaning once again the social compensation I mentioned.
Normally I¬¥d say you were right, freedoms shoudl be protected even against the general common good, in this case though the climate crisis is of such importance that, as I said, even these more darstic measures have to be taken.
And I do think that it would make quite a big change if you pair it with several similar mesaures, as it has been said in the video the emissions by this sector makes up, if I remember correctly, nearly 30% of the averages persons emmissions, a factor quite easy to lower.
author: Marvin Jung

text: ‚Äã¬†@Marvin Jung¬† There are numerous articles/news posts about this issue and all reach to the same conclusion: cutting meat doesn't make that much of a difference. It still won't make that much of a difference if it is implemented on top of some of the measures I've mentioned. It is just insignificant. Additionally, when you force people to follow such useless rules, people simply won't comply which will create other problems. I don't think people would be happy to forcefully go vegetarian. Anyways, I think we agree to disagree because I can see this debate going forever haha. I enjoyed debating with you, mate. Have a good day!

text: What this video does not examine further is how the farming practices largely influence overall emissions. Cows, while big producers of methane, have the incredible ability to aid in carbon SEQUESTRATION through the fertility their manure provides to land. Since the demand of beef is so high and people eat so much of it (just eat less), farmers have been pressured to raising beef the most profitable way, typically not through responsible practices. But by no means are cows the problem, we are. Instead cows could actually be part of the solution through responsible holistic management like intensive rotational grazing and composting on site. The reality of crops and beef being raised separately disrupts the possible cycle of fertility that could actually aid in soil building, and offset the methane emissions a herd produced.

text:
This is dangerous advice, humans need meat!

Ruminant animals can actually reverse climate change and reclaim land. Cow droppings actually trap methane in the soil, enriching it. Look up Allan Savory, he knows a thing or two about agriculture. I think we can all agree that factory farming is bad, but meat is not only good, it is essential for human health, especially in times like these where a strong immune system is vital. A vegan diet is far worse for the environment, plants often need to be imported, and imagine replacing manure with synthetic fertiliser. A vegan world is a plastic, toxic world.

text: Actually, there is a misunderstanding about contribution of beef in green house emissions specific to Indian context. The statement "beef industry causes global warming" is only true in West, where there is seperate industrial livestock farming for meat. Those breed are fast-growing high weight-gaining category specially grown for meat. They are not much useful for dairy industry, which has other type of breeds. In India, there is no industrial livestock farming for beef. Almost all methane emissions in India is from cattle grown for milk. Our dairy farmers and farms give them for slaughter only once they run dry (no more able to produce milk) which forms major part of beef supply in India. For small farmers, this is the money they use to buy next cow. In fact, beef consumption in India helps reduce methane emission, because they remove such cattle from population, which otherwise will continue to emit it. Point is, dairy farms are major culprits. If anybody genuinely cares about this issue, the best way is reverse "White revolution" and promote reduction milk consumption.

text:
¬†@Prime Arch¬† because the Western countries has high GDP per capita. The more GDP a country has, the more products that country produces. 
GDP means the total value of goods and services produced by an economy annually. 
When India's GDP per capita increase, its carbon emission per capita will also increase.
China is an example.
In the 20th century, China had a very low carbon emission per capita but today, their per capita carbon emission is very high.
When the GDP per capita of China skyrocketed, their carbon emissions per capita also skyrocketed.

The same is happening to India nowadays. Haven't you seen how fast the per capita carbon emissions of India raised in just a few years?
author: Mathew Jose

text:
‚Äã¬†@Crusty Sock¬† Here in Mexico, there's a growing number of people who are going back to their roots. Our ancestors didn't have cows, pigs, or chickens. They ate predominately plant-based with ingredients like corn, amaranth, cacao, avocado, chile, varieties of mushrooms, squash, onion, nopales, vanilla, all sorts of fruits, native vegetables unknown in other parts of the world, and so much more. 


The way I started interpreting it is that plant-based eating can be a tribute to my country and it's people.

text:
Please realise this is the AMERICAN model of farming, VOX have not used the UK farming model due to the fact that it is a carbon sink (Taking in more carbon than is emitted) but this does not account for the methane. The UK model also uses 'unfarmable' land to graze livestock, areas that are not farmable to any other 'crop'. This is grass lands that when the cattle are circulated from field to field, regrows, draws back in more carbon, before being eaten again by the returning livestock heard.


Yes the methane is a factor that we must look at, and the vast amount of Beef that we consume worldwide should be reduced. But if done correctly, then it can work for us in the long term.

text:
As a student studying Geology and Climate Science in school, it makes me really sad how much people deny global warming. It‚Äôs not hard to understand.
Earth is a greenhouse naturally thanks to CO2, O2, CH4, N2O, and others. Without them Earth won‚Äôt be habitable, but add too much, you offset the climate. Everything is balanced. But humans are dramatically offsetting that balance and sending Earths into rapid warming 20x faster than the rate it took us heading into the PETM 56 million years ago. When our planet was 3¬∞ to 4¬∞ cooler 20,000 years ago, North America was covered in an ice sheet several hundred feet thick, the modern Holoence gave rise to modern humanity, 4¬∞ or 5¬∞C hotter than today in just a century. Human civilization will struggle. 
And it sickens me when people say ‚Äúit‚Äôs a scam a hoax‚Äù when scientists are trying to address an issue, science is important, it saves lives, being in denial, you cause problems. I really wish sometimes people in politics were actual scientists so we
can fix these problems. 
Climate change is real and the solution is easier than the problem but either people are ignorant or just don‚Äôt care and don‚Äôt act. I‚Äôm not saying we have 12 years to live, and humanity (maybe) could adapt to it, but why risk it and make our future generations suffer? 
While Global Warming and Cooling events in Earths history have never completely wiped out life on Earth. They have been responsible for mass extinction events nearly every time. It‚Äôs ridiculous, science denial is dangerous.

text:
Rice's global warming footprint isn't that bad. Meats, chocolates and coffees are worse according to the chart.

However, the real issue with rice is the huge amount of water it requires in agriculture. The fields where rice plants are grown are literally flooded to prevent other weeds from growing. Only rice can grow in a flooded field. Many dams in Asia provide free irrigation to these fields. These dams provide more water to the rice fields than to other uses, like as drinkwater, combined. In a time when a global water crisis is also looming, rice agriculture will need to change if Asia doesn't want to run out of freshwater.

Beef = Beef (beef herd) (Beef from cattle raised for their meat)
Beef (Dairy) = Beef (dairy herd) (Beef from dairy production herd)
Cheese = Cheese

text:
‚Ä¢ Cheese causes extra emissions due to the processing required to turn milk into cheese.
‚Ä¢ Milk is non-cow sources which is the most common source outside of western countries, and it's low.
‚Ä¢ Cow-milk requires cows, so it's higher than non-cow milk.
‚Ä¢ Beef requires extra processing on top of the base emissions from cows.
‚Ä¢ One cow can produce milk repeatedly, but it can produce beef only once, hence beef is so much higher than milk.
Chicken stew can never compare

text:
It would be interesting to see this graph compared to the relative cost per calorie for each food.

Beef, poultry and the entire meat industry is heavily subsidized by taxpayers, whether it's imported or domestic. While produce and plant based foods are better for the environment, the cost to consumers is much higher. That's just one of the reasons why a lot of working class and poor people eat meat rich diets. If we readjusted our legislative priorities in terms of how we subsidize food production and made the cost of meat reflect its true cost to our society, far fewer people would eat it as often. This is a market solution to the problem, which conservatives praise as the best way to approach public policy, yet they steadfastly oppose such ideas by falsely labeling it as government controlling what you can or can't eat, because meat producing companies are a big contributor to GOP politicians.

text:
¬†@Mario Reyes¬† 
CO2 is 1/2200 of our atmosphere.
It does not hold or retain heat.
The sun supplies 99.7% of all light and heat the earth receives.
Most are aware of the suns 11 year cycle, which repeats.
Is it possible the sun has other cycles, conveniently not mentioned?
Every 230-260 years the suns output of heat and light drops to a low point.
Our sun is a dynamo that generates output, stable enough it does vary due to conditions within.
Valentina Zharkova, a mathematician and Astrophysicist used Nasa data to develop a predictive algorithm that supports and explains why this occurs.
Three distinct areas of circulating  plasma, always interracting, sometimes inhibit and at other times reinforce generated wavelength strength.
If you understand anything about electricity you will understand three phase output is greater than a single phase.
Then think of a motor that ramps up or down, its output varies, as does its corresponding magnetic field strength.
The sun presently is at the lowest point of magnetic fieldcstrength invhundreds of years.
Our history clearly shows this happens repeatedly, the last being the dark ages, where heightened volcanic and earthquake activity took place.
Temperatures began to cool and winter season became longer with each passing year.
The cycle lasts about 30-50 years.
Roy Spencer was a Nasa scientist tasked with running a planned experiment, using satellite data to prove the Greenhouse effect.
Spencers conclusion was that the effect was minimal and certainly far less than expected.
So what did proven science do.
Criticized and then ignored him.
This is how an agenda works.
Dont take my word for it.
Research:
Henrik Svensmark 
Valentina Zharkova
Roy Spencer
About three months ago, a Euorpean organization representing 23 different countries petitioned the UN towards holding open discussion on climate change.
There message, There is no Emergency, change is largely by natural causation

text: ¬†@Sam Al¬† This is a lot of feel good optimism but the reality is that no matter how many people decide to make that individual decision, the effective method here is to stop irresponsible production at the source. That source being corporations who knowingly sacrifice our Earth for the sake of profit. For the most part, individual boycotts are barely negligible in the modern age because large-scale meat producers also typically own several non-meat brands/products. That holds true for many non-meat yet also environmentally detrimental brands. Regulation is the way to go.

text: Americans eating beef have little to no effect on deforestation in Brazil. Most ranch land in the US is not suitable for farming nor was there a massive deforestation effort that took place. The same Great Plains that were an ideal feeding ground for the wild buffalo of our past are just as ideal for the cows of today. In fact trying to turn that land into an industrial farmland is much more detrimental to the environment than simply letting cows graze on it. Also cow belches (methane) eventually breaks down into CO2 and rejoins the carbon cycle. The carbon doesn‚Äôt come from fossil fuels thus we can treat it as carbon neutral just like we treat biodiesel as carbon neutral.
